natural problem: How many ways are there to choose 3 cards from a standard deck of 52 cards, if all three cards must be of different suits?  (Assume that the order of the cards does not matter.)
natural solution: First, we choose the suits. There are $\binom{4}{3}=4$ ways to do this. Then, we choose one of 13 cards from each of the chosen suits. There are $13^3=2197$ ways to do this. The total number of ways to choose 3 cards of different suits is therefore $4\cdot 2197=\boxed{8788}$.

a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes nCk :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "nCk = (\<lambda>n k. fact n div (fact k * fact (n - k)))"
shows  "nCk 52 3 - nCk 13 3 * 4 = 8788"
a_0.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 How many ways are there to choose 3 cards from a standard deck of 52 cards, if all three cards must be of different suits?  (Assume that the order of the cards does not matter.) The final Answer is 8788
 ### Proof
 First, we choose the suits. There are $\binom{4}{3}=4$ ways to do this. Then, we choose one of 13 cards from each of the chosen suits. There are $13^3=2197$ ways to do this. The total number of ways to choose 3 cards of different suits is therefore $4\cdot 2197=\boxed{8788}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes nCk :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "nCk = (\<lambda>n k. fact n div (fact k * fact (n - k)))"
shows  "nCk 52 3 - nCk 13 3 * 4 = 8788"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_0.informal problem: Find the difference between the number of ways to choose 3 cards from a deck of 52 cards and 4 times the number of ways to choose 3 cards from a suit of 13 cards. The final answer is 8788.

a_1.formal problem:
theorem
fixes choose :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "\<forall>n r. choose n r = fact n div (fact r * fact (n - r))"
and h1 : "choose 52 3 = 22100"
shows  "8788 = (\<Sum>i\<in>{0..3}. choose 13 i * choose 13 (3 - i))"
a_1.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 How many ways are there to choose 3 cards from a standard deck of 52 cards, if all three cards must be of different suits?  (Assume that the order of the cards does not matter.) The final Answer is 8788
 ### Proof
 First, we choose the suits. There are $\binom{4}{3}=4$ ways to do this. Then, we choose one of 13 cards from each of the chosen suits. There are $13^3=2197$ ways to do this. The total number of ways to choose 3 cards of different suits is therefore $4\cdot 2197=\boxed{8788}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes choose :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "\<forall>n r. choose n r = fact n div (fact r * fact (n - r))"
and h1 : "choose 52 3 = 22100"
shows  "8788 = (\<Sum>i\<in>{0..3}. choose 13 i * choose 13 (3 - i))"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_1.informal problem: A committee of 3 members is to be chosen from a group of 52 people. If there are 22,100 possible ways to choose the committee, find the sum of the products of the ways to choose $i$ members from the first 13 people and $3-i$ members from the remaining 39 people, where $i$ ranges from 0 to 3. The final answer is 8,788.

assumes h0 : "combinations n k = (fact n) div (fact k * fact (n - k))"
shows  "combinations 52 3 - (\<Sum>i\<in>{0..12}. combinations 13 3) * 4 = 8788"

a_2.informal problem: How many ways can you choose 3 cards from a standard deck of 52 cards, such that none of the 3 cards are of the same suit? The final answer is 8788.

and h1 : "count_cards_with_diff_suits 3 = 8788"
shows  "choose_cards_with_diff_suits 3 n = 8788"

a_3.informal problem: There are 52 cards in a deck. Find the number of ways to choose 3 cards, each with a different suit. The final answer is 8,788.

a_4.formal problem:
theorem
fixes n :: nat
assumes h0 : "n = 52"
and h1 : "n = 13 * 4"
and h2 : "card (sets_of_size {1..n} 3) = 8788"
shows  "card {A. A \<subseteq> {1..n} \<and> card A = 3 \<and> (\<forall>a b. a \<in> A \<and> b \<in> A \<and> a \<noteq> b \<longrightarrow> a mod 13 \<noteq> b mod 13)} = 8788"
a_4.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 How many ways are there to choose 3 cards from a standard deck of 52 cards, if all three cards must be of different suits?  (Assume that the order of the cards does not matter.) The final Answer is 8788
 ### Proof
 First, we choose the suits. There are $\binom{4}{3}=4$ ways to do this. Then, we choose one of 13 cards from each of the chosen suits. There are $13^3=2197$ ways to do this. The total number of ways to choose 3 cards of different suits is therefore $4\cdot 2197=\boxed{8788}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes n :: nat
assumes h0 : "n = 52"
and h1 : "n = 13 * 4"
and h2 : "card (sets_of_size {1..n} 3) = 8788"
shows  "card {A. A \<subseteq> {1..n} \<and> card A = 3 \<and> (\<forall>a b. a \<in> A \<and> b \<in> A \<and> a \<noteq> b \<longrightarrow> a mod 13 \<noteq> b mod 13)} = 8788"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_4.informal problem: There are 52 cards in a deck, which can be represented as 13 sets of 4 cards, one for each suit. How many ways can you choose a set of 3 cards such that no two cards in the set have the same modulo 13? The final answer is 8788.

a_6.formal problem:
theorem
fixes nCr :: "(nat \<times> nat) \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "nCr = (\<lambda>(n, r). fact n div (fact r * fact (n - r)))"
and h1 : "52 = 4 * 13"
shows  "nCr (13, 1) * nCr (13, 1) * nCr (13, 1) * nCr (4, 3) = 8788"

 proof-

a_6.informal problem: How many ways can you choose 1 card from each of the 4 suits of a standard 52-card deck and 3 more cards from the remaining 48 cards? The final answer is 8788.

a_7.formal problem:
theorem
fixes ways :: nat
assumes h0 : "ways = (\<Sum>k1\<leftarrow>[0..<13]. \<Sum>k2\<leftarrow>[0..<13]. \<Sum>k3\<leftarrow>[0..<13]. \<Sum>k4\<leftarrow>[0..<13].
                  (if k1 + k2 + k3 + k4 = 3 \<and> k1 * k2 * k3 * k4 > 0 then 1 else 0))"
shows  "ways = 8788"
a_7.formal solution:

 How many ways are there to choose 3 cards from a standard deck of 52 cards, if all three cards must be of different suits?  (Assume that the order of the cards does not matter.) The final Answer is 8788

                  (if k1 + k2 + k3 + k4 = 3 \<and> k1 * k2 * k3 * k4 > 0 then 1 else 0))"

a_7.informal problem: Find the number of ways to choose four non-negative integers $k_1, k_2, k_3, k_4$ such that their sum is 3 and their product is greater than 0. The final answer is 8788.

a_8.formal problem:
theorem
fixes nCr :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "nCr 52 3 = (\<Prod> i<3. (52 - i)) div (fact 3)"
and h1 : "nCr 13 1 = (\<Prod> i<1. (13 - i)) div (fact 1)"
and h2 : "nCr 4 3 = (\<Prod> i<3. (4 - i)) div (fact 3)"
shows  "nCr 52 3 - nCr 13 1 * nCr 4 3 = 8788"
a_8.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 How many ways are there to choose 3 cards from a standard deck of 52 cards, if all three cards must be of different suits?  (Assume that the order of the cards does not matter.) The final Answer is 8788
 ### Proof
 First, we choose the suits. There are $\binom{4}{3}=4$ ways to do this. Then, we choose one of 13 cards from each of the chosen suits. There are $13^3=2197$ ways to do this. The total number of ways to choose 3 cards of different suits is therefore $4\cdot 2197=\boxed{8788}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes nCr :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "nCr 52 3 = (\<Prod> i<3. (52 - i)) div (fact 3)"
and h1 : "nCr 13 1 = (\<Prod> i<1. (13 - i)) div (fact 1)"
and h2 : "nCr 4 3 = (\<Prod> i<3. (4 - i)) div (fact 3)"
shows  "nCr 52 3 - nCr 13 1 * nCr 4 3 = 8788"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_8.informal problem: In how many ways can you choose 3 cards from a standard 52-card deck such that there is not exactly one card from each of the four suits? The final answer is 8788.

a_9.formal problem:
theorem
fixes choose :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "choose = (\<lambda>n k. if k = 0 \<or> k = n then 1 else choose (n - 1) k + choose (n - 1) (k - 1))"
and h1 : "choose 52 3 = 22100"
shows  "choose 13 1 * choose 39 2 = 8788"
a_9.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 How many ways are there to choose 3 cards from a standard deck of 52 cards, if all three cards must be of different suits?  (Assume that the order of the cards does not matter.) The final Answer is 8788
 ### Proof
 First, we choose the suits. There are $\binom{4}{3}=4$ ways to do this. Then, we choose one of 13 cards from each of the chosen suits. There are $13^3=2197$ ways to do this. The total number of ways to choose 3 cards of different suits is therefore $4\cdot 2197=\boxed{8788}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes choose :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "choose = (\<lambda>n k. if k = 0 \<or> k = n then 1 else choose (n - 1) k + choose (n - 1) (k - 1))"
and h1 : "choose 52 3 = 22100"
shows  "choose 13 1 * choose 39 2 = 8788"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_9.informal problem: The choose function is defined as follows: $C(n,k) = \begin{cases} 1, & \mbox{if }k = 0 \mbox{ or }k = n \\ C(n-1, k) + C(n-1, k-1), & \mbox{otherwise} \end{cases}$. Given that $C(52,3) = 22100$, find the value of $C(13,1) \times C(39,2)$. The final answer is 8788.
